A Risk Management Program (RMP) has been implemented at Rust-Oleum's Hagerstown facility for the reduction of accidental releases of hazardous materials. The RMP summarizes the management, administrative, procedural, and technological controls that work together to minimize the risk to the community of hazardous chemical releases. The Risk Management Plan is organized to correspond with specific U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) RMP definitions and requirements, including:



A? Hagerstown policies to protect health, environment, and safety;

A? Facility identification and regulated substances covered processes;

A? Hazard Assessment;

A? Prevention Program;

A? Five-Year Accident History;

A? Emergency Response Plan; and

A? Planned changes to improve safety.



HAGERSTOWN POLICIES TO PROTECT HEALTH, ENVIRONMENT, AND SAFETY

Risk management and safety are important concerns at Hagerstown; this RMP formalizes and documents these activities. Hagerstown is committed to conducting its operations in a safe and responsible manner and to reducing risks to human health and to the environment.



FACILITY IDENTIFICATION

The Rust-Oleum Corporation owns and operates a paint manufacturing plant in Hagerstown, Maryland. LP gas (propane/butane mixture) is used at the facility as a propellant for aerosol paints. LP gas is a regulated flammable RMP substance with a threshold quantity for accidental release prevention of 10,000 pounds.  The amount of LP gas  present in the system is approximately 133,580 pounds.   



HAZARD ASSESSMENT - WORST CASE SCENARIOS (WCS)

The WCS was determined using EPA's OCA Guidance document.



HAZARD ASSESSMENT - ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIOS (ARS)

The ARS was determined using EPA's OCA Guidance document.



GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

A prevention program is in place to minimize the risk of hazardous chemical releases in accordance with the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) standard (29 CFR 1910.119) and the EPA Risk

Management Program. This prevention program covers the entire paint  process,  in which LP gas is present above the threshold quantity for both PSM and RMP rules. 

The prevention program provides a structured approach to preventing accidents. Some of the specific activities in the prevention program include:

A? Process safety information is provided to all employees upon hire and is accessible at all times.

A? In-depth process hazard analyses are completed every five years by qualified personnel using

  techniques approved under the PSM standard.

A? Written operating procedures (kept up-to-date) are used for training and guiding the work of operators.

A? Training is provided to all employees upon hire, and refresher training is given annually or upon request.

A? Operators, mechanics, and contractor personnel are qualified, trained in the general hazards in the

  facility, and informed of any temporary situations affecting safety.

A? Pre-startup safety reviews are conducted to insure that conditions for safe operation have been satisfied

  prior to starting new or modified equipment.

A? A program is in place to maintain the mechanical integrity of the process, which includes written

  procedures, training requirements, work orders, scheduled maintenance, and computerized

  documentation.

A? A hot work permit system assures that work is done safely and properly.

A? A management of change system is in place to ensure that changes are managed safely.

A? Incidents are investigated and actions are taken as part of a continuous improvement effort.

A? Routine audits are conducted to assure that safe practices are being followed. 

A? Employee participation is ensured through an active "Facility Safety Committee".



This systematic approach to process safety at Hagerstown involves employees and strives for continuing improvements in overall safety. The training, qualifications, and safety awareness of our operations, maintenance, and management personnel a

re a key element in reducing and mitigating accidents.



FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

This facility has reported no incidents during a five-year history that resulted in an accidental release from covered processes that incurred deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage. 



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN

Hagerstown has an emergency response plan to ensure that in the event of an emergency the personnel are aware of the appropriate actions to take and authorities to contact in order to mitigate the effects of a release.  Response activities are coordinated with the Williamsport Fire Department.
